brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of this study is to determine whether head rotation in prone positon affects
      regional cerebral oxygenation (rSO2)in anesthetized patients undergoing lower back surgery.

clinical_study.brief_title: Study of the: Effect of Head Rotation in Prone Position on Regional Cerebral Oxygen Saturation.
clinical_study.condition: Regional Cerebral Oxygen Saturation During Head Rotation

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Lower back surgery

          -  Age [18-80]

          -  ASA group I-III

          -  free and painless movement of the neck (including flexion, extension and rotation)

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Pain during neck movement as mentioned under inclusion criteria.

          -  known history of cervical spine pathology or pathology of central nervous system
             including cerebrovascular disease

          -  any stenosis of the carotid vessels or known symptoms associated with such

          -  BMI > 35

study_pop.textblock:
Patients undergoing lowerback surgery under universal anesthesia at Glostrup Hospital,
        Copenhagen.

clinical_study.official_title: Observation Study of the: Effect of Head Rotation in Prone Position on Regional Cerebral Oxygen Saturation (rSO2) in Anesthetized Patients.

primary_outcome.description: Before, during and immediately after awaking from anesthesia

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: During stay at the post anesthetic care unit. Any new neurological symptoms, pain from the neck, visual symptoms etc.

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Case-Only, Time Perspective: Prospective
